News

"Stop Circuit Laundry" campaign launched on campus

By Gracie Daw

The campaign has over 500 signatures from students and demands that the University of York end their contract with Circuit Laundry

Open Letter sent to the Vice Chancellor arguing against pay cut for marking boycott

By James Clay

York academics and students respond to pay cut for staff participating in marking boycott

Nouse interviews students standing as candidates for the local council

By James Clay

Student council candidates share their thoughts in the run up to the local elections

York set for 2023 local council elections

By James Clay

Lib Dems and Labour battle it out to take overall majority control of the City of York Council.

Labour gain control of the council after winning local elections

By James Clay

A disappointing night for the Lib Dems and Greens in York as Labour reach a majority of council seats

University announces death of Long Boi

By Gracie Daw

The University released a statement on the Radio 1 Breakfast show saying they were "forced to conclude he has passed away"

"Stop Circuit Laundry" campaign launched on campus

By Gracie Daw

The campaign has over 500 signatures from students and demands that the University of York end their contract with Circuit Laundry

Open Letter sent to the Vice Chancellor arguing against pay cut for marking boycott

By James Clay

York academics and students respond to pay cut for staff participating in marking boycott

By James Clay

Student council candidates share their thoughts in the run up to the local elections

York set for 2023 local council elections

By James Clay

Lib Dems and Labour battle it out to take overall majority control of the City of York Council.

Labour gain control of the council after winning local elections

By James Clay

A disappointing night for the Lib Dems and Greens in York as Labour reach a majority of council seats

University announces death of Long Boi

By Gracie Daw

The University released a statement on the Radio 1 Breakfast show saying they were "forced to conclude he has passed away"

BNP officer verbally abuses students

Several University of York students have allegedly been targeted and threatened by a British National Party official amidst concerns about increasing BNP activity in York.

Investigation reveals weakness in Chemistry security protocol

Fears over the security of dangerous chemicals in the Chemistry Department have been raised after Nouse gained entry to a secure building intended only to be accessible to Chemistry students and staff.

Viking Raid t-shirts bought from unethical supplier

YUSU AND RAG have come under increased scrutiny this week following their use of the non-Fair Trade supplier Fruit of the Loom for Viking Raid merchandise.

RAG success breaks records

York RAG week has been an unprecedented success this year, raising in excess of PS16,000 for charities such as York Nightstop, Survive, Teenage Cancer Trust and the Make a Wish Foundation. This makes it by far the most successful RAG week on record, beating the previous year's RAG week by more than PS12,500.

York struggles to overcome its reputation for lack of diversity

Are we living in a monoculture? <em>Nicky Woolf</em> and <em>Raf Sanchez</em> take an in-depth look at the underlying reasons for the University of York's lack of ethnic diversity.

York tensions between 'town and gown'

York has been singled out in the Guardian's report of their Higher Education Summit as an area where tensions between 'town and gown' are unusually high, as yet another petition is presented to the York City Council by the Badger Hill Action Group against multiple-occupancy lets.

Amnesty International Society stage Palestinian 'check-point'

The University of York's Amnesty International Society staged a demonstration on Saturday 3 February in Parliament Square to raise awareness of the existing situation in Palestine.

Archbishop speaks out against Reid

The Archbishop of York has spoken out against the Government for bringing Britain "close to a police state." Speaking on ITV News on 5 February, the Rt. Rev John Sentamu compared Government plans for 90 day detentions of terror suspects to measures in place in Uganda under Idi Amin.

Concerns raised over Vanbrugh's future

The extensive building works taking place near Wentworth College will become a new set of blocks for Vanbrugh College, which will cost around PS10 million, according to current predictions. The 'Bleachfield' project, which will divide Vanbrugh over a number of sites, has raised concerns over the cohesion of the college's future.

Spoof letters spark University enquiry

THE UNIVERSITY of York is carrying out a "confidential investigation" into the running of Derwent College on the strength of spoof letters written by a student to a number of national figures. The Derwent student sent letters to Tony Blair, the Queen, the BBC, John Grogan, MP for Selby, and Costcutter under the psuedonym 'Julian Bassey', complaining that the college continues to "violently ignore" his letters about Derwent's kitchen facilities.

Derwent abandons catered-only plans

PLANS TO introduce full catering in Derwent College next year have been abandoned. The college will remain fully self-catered and will go through further renovations of facilities.

Student trapped in flooding Dusk toilet

DUSK BAR was flooded on 31 January after a University of York student who got stuck in the bar toilets was asked by staff to climb out through the window. This damaged the cistern and caused water to burst from the exposed pipes.

JCR budgets decided

ON MONDAY 5 February the distribution of the remaining fund provided by the University for its Junior Common Room Committees was decided by YUSU Finance Committee.

UGM motions fail again

ON MONDAY 30 JANUARY 13 motions were proposed at the UGM. All of these failed to meet the threshold of numbers needed to ratify them as YUSU policy, with the exception of the motion regarding Portering.

Student convicted of rape

By James Bithell

UNIVERSITY OF York student Clive Richard Manyou was convicted of raping and sexually assaulting another student as she slept, and sentenced to six years in prison at a trial in York Crown Court last week. Manyou, 36, of Heslington, raped and sexually assaulted a 19 year-old female student after "manipulating" his way into her room in the early hours of 8 June 2006. Manyou was studying English and Related Literature at York, and was well known as lead singer of the successful campus band Mitus. - <a href="http://www.nouse.co.uk/2007/01/24/courtroom-sketch/">Courtroom Sketch</a> - <a href="http://www.nouse.co.uk/2007/01/24/student-shock-as-mitus-lead-singer-is-convicted/">Student Shock</a>

Courtroom Sketch

By James Bithell

Student shock as York lead singer is convicted

By James Bithell

Neo-fascist website targets York ex-students and staff

By James Bithell

A UNIVERSITY of York Professor and several ex-York students have been targeted by a far right fascist website with links to the British National Party (BNP) and violent neo-Nazi groups.

Porter shortage sparks crisis

By James Bithell

DERWENT, VANBRUGH, and Wentworth porters' lodges are to close in the wake of "protracted issues" between porters and management and amid concerns over student welfare.

Secular and religious groups clash over issue of free speech

<em>Nicky Woolf</em> and <em>Raf Sanchez</em> talk to the York Jewish and Islamic Societies and the Christian Union about the role of religion and the rise of 'secular fundamentalism'

Entwistle's family proclaim his innocence as he is refused bail

By James Bithell

THE PARENTS of ex-University of York student Neil Entwistle have spoken for the first time about their son's impending trial for the murder of his wife and child, just as Entwistle has been returned to jail after a psychiatric evaluation determined he was not suicidal.

Budget cuts across campus

AS THE University prepares to enter a new phase of expansion, it is faced with the prospect of slashed budgets following a schedule of departmental reviews, with the result that departments are being encouraged to make savings wherever possible, including on staffing levels, to help bring the University out of deficit.

Campus bars remain in threat of closure

THE HEAD of Commercial Services, Jon Greenwood, has made a plea to students to return to campus bars after a recent downturn has left them running on a deficit. Despite the implementation of the Model 29+ plan in October, under which the seven campus bars are closed for a total of 20 nights over a week, they are still not meeting running costs as a group.

Student 'permanently disfigured by bedbugs' in rented 2Let house

SU accused of 'homophobia'

University labelled sexist

Ftr are cause of controversy once more

THE BUS COMPANY 'First' has been paid another PS250,000 by the City of York Council and bus ticket prices are to be raised again. The unpopular Ftr bus project was originally billed at PS450,000 but has already cost the city more than 1.5 million pounds.

Campus rents to increase by 7%

Hes.East debate runs on

Students live in York squat
